reviewText:
UPDATE: Holy shiat this dead game got a new update. Oh wait, most of it is locked away behind a paywall! Hahahahahahahahaha-*gasp*-hahahahhaahaha.

Long read ahead, but worth it!

As someone who has played Ace of Spades for way too long, let me introduce the history of it to you first:

In April 2011, somebody called Ben Aksoy released a pretty decent and free FPS with voxel mechanics called Ace of Spades. This was a game that people mostly played on a randomly-generated map similar to Minecraft's randomly-generated maps (only without the trees, only grass, some rivers and more hills). The default and only gamemode at the time was Capture The Flag. All of these in combination allowed for some fun gameplay that required some strategy. Dig tunnels to capture the enemy's intel, or build a fort to defend your own intel. Every man only had a rifle, spade, grenades and some blocks (unlike most FPSes there were no newby spray-and-pray weapons).

As this game rised in popularity, a certain company called Jagex was interested in purchasing Ace of Spades. As Ben needed some money to keep updating his game, he agreed. At first, Jagex kept this a secret as to not interfere with the growing progress of the game, and its community with all of the mods/maps/gamemodes/scripts that they were producing.

And so the game kept updating, but since Jagex's buyout of the game the direction of Ace of Spades had taken a different turn from the old trench-warfare, stragetical FPS it was to a more typical, faster-paced, almost Call of Duty like FPS (SMGs and Shotguns were added, sprinting added, etc). Coupled with new maps such as Hallway and Pinpoint which abondoned some of Ace of Spades' most important features (Hallway doesn't allow you to build a tunnel underground, people usually battle in a very narrow hallway just a few blocks wide, and it's quite easy to just spawncamp if you're at the top, Pinpoint does not allow any tunnels at all, and the whole map is at the same height), and Ace of Spades became not much more than a free Call of Duty + Minecraft game.

And then without much warning, development on Ace of Spades almost halted. Only 1 new version was made that was a beta and was not approved to be an update to the main version of Ace of Spades. And then Jagex had announced that Ace of Spades was to be scrapped to make way for their version of Ace of Spades, almost a completely new game, pretty much alienating almost all of the current Ace of Spades community at that time. At first Jagex's Ace of Spades had some popularity, but as people realised how much the game just sucked in general (lack of timely updates, bugs and glitches, game-balancing issues, etc), and the fact that the game was made by Jagex itself (Jagex do not really have the best reputation of a game company) led to the downfall of the game. Although there have been a few great updates (Classic CTF update, Map Editor update, KV6 modding update), it still doesn't excuse the lack of timely updates, especially if almost all if not all of them brought along some bad features or some bugs.

The new Ace of Spades turned that CoD aspect all the way up to 11, and added some Team Fortress 2 into the mix (while Team Fortress 2 is a very good game by itself, the way it was implemented wasn't). Stuff like Rocket Launchers, Jetpacks, classes were introduced. While some fun could be had in this new game (especially the '30s Gangster game modes, and Classic CTF), it was mostly just a mess. In a typical Ace of Spades match it would not be suprising for you to be accused of hacking" and getting votekicked for it

reviewText:
Do not waste your money. Sometime ago, a game was created by Ben Aksoy (the original creator) based off of World War I that slowly evolved into what is now the old Ace of Spades. The game at the time was free to play, and although it had its quirks -- built on the voxel engine, occassional hackers, and so on -- it was routinely updated, simplistic, and took the FPS genre on a new, exciting, and unexplored path.

For a game of its stature at the time, it was quite entertaining and many of these quirks could be forgiven. Players were able to build structures, destroy structures, and the game struck a unique balance that was perfectly calibrated between the two. Fortifications, trenches, castles and towers -- the original Ace of Spades had it all, and beautifully made landscapes slowly turned into grotesque warzones of battered walls, crumbling buildings, gunfire, and holes from grenades.

Vast networks of tunnels made sure you were always on edge; never sure where the enemy would come up, yet constantly haunted by the sound of their digging beneath your feet. War in the old Ace of Spades was raged across towers and peaks, on the ground in trenches and fortifications, and the crowded blown-out tunnels that fed one's claustrophobia.

There was much work to be done about this game, graphically it was very basic. Gameplay, it was painlessly simple, and it had a direction that it was going, but it didn't lie to you about what kind of game it was. Then Jagex, the makers of Rune Scape, had bought the game from Aksoy. At first, many people within the community watched to see if Jagex would take the game and continue developing it further, exploring this unique and unwandered path of the genre. Up until this point, Aksoy had worked on the game alone; the possibilities of what a team of developers could do with such a game had many excited, and some nervous.

The result of what you have here, is the biggest joke a gaming company has ever committed alongside the likes of the E.T. fiasco that has long faded from memory. Rumours surfaced that Jagex had constricted Aksoy to NDAs, especially after he tried to get the game back. (Pay in mind, unconfirmed rumours) The company then went back on promises it made to the Ace of Spades community, migrated it to a new engine, and took the game away from its potential. They built it around classes, changed things, and made it feel more familiar (though they couldn't even do this right) to the arcade FPS genre styles we've seen in places like Team Fortress. The game quickly became sniper-haven, and the community who had enjoyed the old Aos was outraged.

Jagex's Ace of Spades died out within a year, with the servers becoming vacant and the game no longer interesting. It became nothing more than a rotting, putrified carcass horribly butchered by Jagex's developers; and then left out in the open without so much as a courtesy to bury the poor thing. Ace of Spades died with Jagex, and what was an amazing potential for a game to explore was cut short by a parasitic company. Aksoy has subsequently disappeared, his social media accounts, website -- all of it has been taken down.

I played the original Ace of Spades not long after it was first created. And I was one of the hopefuls that were excited when Jagex purchased the game, and I had to fight for a refund from Steam in a process that took about a month thereafter. Many did the same, and Jagex received tons of refunds. The game turned into such a cookie-cutter disappointment, that I've now eternally labelled Jagex as nothing more than a failed, parasitic company with no ounce of creativity. I've resigned myself to never purchasing a Jagex game in the future, and as we've seen with Rune Scape, and now the recent rumours of them being bought out, they're nothing more than a failed company.

What Jagex has brought to light, however, is a growing problem among the gaming market over overbearing companies -- such as Jagex -- that have eyed indie-games like parasites. Companies that see these indev games as being quick money makers; who prey on these starting out or independent developers to fix their financial, marketing, or creative woes because of their poor management and inability to run a gaming company effectively. Jagex has gone down the road of other publishers such as Electronic Arts and Ubisoft, that have become nothing more than jokes to be laughed at, and companies to be gazed at with suspicion for their tendency to screw over the markets.

And this isn't the only problem the gaming market is facing by these companies. People look at Early Access sales with more apprehension, because of developers that have been successful at wooing the community, raking in cash, and then abandoning the projects (Star Citizen has been pulling people's legs for years now). We've seen companies release games that are nothing more than hollow husks, and all of the actual content is in DLCs priced almost as much as the original game. (Elite Dangerous, Civilisation, Age of Mythology)

We've seen parasitic companies, who have no other intention but to bleed consumers dry and destroy a game as much as possible. (Electronic Arts, Ubisoft, Microsoft, and Jagex) This has, unfortunately, made people more hesitant towards those developers that are actually trying to produce not only quality but original content, and are just trying to break into the market without having to worry about the market titans breathing down their neck. We've seen this now with both Electronic Arts and Ubisoft attempting to drag people away from Steam's platform with Uplay and Origin, because they want to monopolise on the market. So, if you want to ask what is killing the gaming market, and what murdered Ace of Spades -- you may settle your eyes on the grotesque vultures such as Jagex.

What is left of the old Ace of Spades community has recreated the original game. You can play the original voxel-based version now called Build and Shoot, or you can search for the graphically upgraded version called OpenSpades. Both are free and access the same servers. It's unfortunate that what Ace of Spades was meant to be will never come to fruition, and these two community based versions will never be further developed, but they are still very fun to play and still have populated servers.

I understand this review has come out more as a rant, especially against these companies, but it is especially frustrating to see this happen. The best thing that could ever happen to the gaming market is if some of these cancerous companies went bankrupt, that's about all they're worth. However, such a possibility doesn't seem likely, and instead we'll be forever graced by their disappointments.

reviewText:
So, Ace of Spades, a.k.a AoS.

I look at this game and I still remember the times where this game was an awesome game.

AoS 0.75, this was the last version of the game just before jagex bought the project(actually 0.76, but it was never used actually).  The game was known for its simple gameplay, building, mods, and, the most important thing, you could run it in a potato.
But the project was sold to jagex. Shortly after they released the payed version of the game 1.0. This version removed all the glamour of the version before, by adding weird classes, premade buildings(that nobody uses by the way) and you could destroy the blocks really easyly...I could spend the rest of the day talking about it. And you couldn't run in your potato anymore!

But the old community(just like myself) didn't like all these changes, and created a new website that hosts the old version of the game(0.75 and 0.76) called buildandshoot.com. At first it was great! But there was no more development of the game, and most game modes are not played anymore(mainly CTF, which was an hour round trying to protect and capture enemy flag. The tricky part here is that you could build tunnels, walk around the map, destroy enemy defenses, create traps, stealth to the enemy flag and come back in one piece, not to mention the maps were huge) and slowly the community started to die.

Now there is no more of what it used to be.

The best game I ever played now there is no more of it.
How sad.

reviewText:
The game that combined Minecraft and CoD, a concept to remember. The trailer outlined a game that would be ever so popular with gamer and player alike. This is not that game. A bland surface of my expectations, this has let me down to the point of regret. With a bland combat system and elements of blocks that just don't seem to fit, the combination of Minecraft and CoD almost couldn't have been done worse.

3/10

An absolutely fantastic concept with elements, that if improved, would have been fantastic. The idea of creating an enviroment that you can play in is a wonderful idea, especially if used during a First Person Shooter like this were the landscape is so interactive. I only wish this was a better game.

All these variables seemed like they were taped together, it seems like the developers put more money in the trailer than the game. The elements of this game are a fantastic match, but rather being wed in a wonderful flurry of passion they are merely going for coffee for the rest of their lives. So much potential, just no effort put into execution, similar to CoD all the developers cared about was money.

A counter recommendation I have would be Brick Force, a game where these pieces are put together in a format that is much more streamline that this. It has many elements of pay-to-play, but as a free to play player I have successfully achieved very high ranks against people a much higher level than me

reviewText:
If you see a guy write a review about how bad a game is with only 101 minutes in, and it's on a free weekend, then you know this game just sucks.

No spawn protection, teams entirely made up of nothing but snipers, bullets go EVERYWHERE, even if you aim at the guy. Maps are un-balanced, most servers host Zombie games, and you usually end up as a zombie anyway, since they are always active.

Griefers everywhere, you can either blow up your own base or blow up the enemy teams, most of the people you are with lag terrifically and are sitting ducks if you have a excellent computer.

Achievements unobtainable. Fufilled requirements of most and I didn't get a single damn one.

Useless leveling system. Get random awards for doing nothing. Where do Reload kills, distraction and other things come in when all I'm doing is walking through a gamebreaking tunnel?

Teams that are strategic ALWAYS LOSE. Teams full of Marksmen ALWAYS WIN.

Many game breaking paths are included in maps, London has a subway tunnel that leads to the enemy base, all you have to do is go miner, take some ammo and use the MPG to rip apart the base, and then you win the match.

Ammo, Medkits and Block refill crates are always put in inconvienet places, you have to walk through a field of snipers before you can even try to touch it.

Landmines kill everyone, so often times, teammates will set up landmines in front of the base, blowing the whole base up.

Engineers are the weakest and worst class EVER. The only thing good about them is their huge block limit and their huge array of instant structures.

Turrets self destruct after 10 seconds, and when used, blow a HUGE hole into the floor, leaving a huge crater. Engies will often place turrets in the base and then ruin the base so you can get picked off by the 400,000 snipers every 12 seconds.

Miner's TNT doesn't really do much damage to blocks at all, the miners tunnel cannon is nifty for wiping out snipers and bases.

If you want to win against snipers, go miner, get double barrel shotgun and take out an entire team by sneaking up behind everyone, since they're all most likely going to be marksmen targeting your team mates.

Don't bother with this game, go play Build and Shoot (Ace of spades Classic)

reviewText:
Ace of Spades. It truly was an ace, once, believe it or not. It was free, buggy, and hackers were sure to get banned. Back before it was on Steam.
Now, I played it on free weekend. It deserves to be on free weekend, eternally, as it's buggy. I can run the classic AoS on my computer, no doubt. This one, seems to focus on graphics, instead of gameplay or engine. It's laggy, even with all the graphics set to low. I have a very new computer, and it should run fine. Haha, no.
The servers are swarming with hackers. All the classes are over powered in one way, and severely underpowered in another. In fact, they're all rip-offs of them- Sniper/Marksman, Soldier/Commando, Engineer/Engineer, and the only original class is Miner. Back in the old days, no classes. Smooth. And now it's slow moving and you can't even run without getting nauseas. All the old gamemodes are gone or renamed, and severely nurfed. I used to love the old gamemodes, but now there's basically only two gamemodes, zombies/deathmatch and capture the something. Construction is severely edited, in that it's too complex and unlike the old strictly cube it was in classic. There's also the fact that the servers seem to be runned on potatoes, even the ones based where I live.
So, would I buy it? For 2.99, probably, if you like cheap, crappy games like me. 14.99? Pha! Just add it to the pile of taboo games in the corner- WarZ, 2066, and all the other knock-offs sold at unbelievably high price. Yes, fifteen bucks is far, far overpriced for this Team Fortress 2/Minecraft knockoff. Go play the classic, it's far better.

reviewText:
I loved the classic Ace of Spades. So, like many people, I was excited to see a more evolved version of an already great game. What I got was an evolved version of a great game, that happened to be so poorly optimized it was unplayable. They patch this, and I had a blast. For a short time. But every update things got worse, and worse, and WORSE.

The movement feels bad, the building is basic, everyone goes marksman because he's so OP, the list goes on.

The DLC which I payed for became free, and the people who bought it got jack s*** for paying them.

The last enjoyment I had from Ace of Spades was creating skins. But shortly after that, they removed the ability to put those skins into the game. That kind of made all my effort seem more like a waste of time.

Do not buy this game. The developers seem to have no interest in listening to the community, the game has about as much personality as a shoe in a dumpster, and it's just so booooring!

reviewText:
Great gameplay, but no tutorials or explanations make it near impossible to be a new player. 3/10, do not recommend unless you really like being thrown in blind.

Gameplay: After I learned how to play on an empty server (I feel lucky to have found one) I felt that most of it was well done. Knock buildings down by cutting out the base, cut the bottom block out of a tree to destroy the whole thing, simple destruction. The building system was extremely confusing and I never did learn to use it, and other players also seemed to not fully understand the build and destroy system. I'd see players build a tower into the sky to be safe, and enemies would run at him rather than cut down his tower. I couldn't build structures over people and turrets, but when I placed turrets they'd be built over to destroy them and I'd be burried to become easy prey.

Graphics: Not much was expected, being a blocky build and shoot game, but it was actually decently done. The characters animations seemed to work around structures (no legs clipping through stairs) and explosions through out debris to bounce around.

Classes: The four classes in the game were well explained and each unique. For each game mode there was a clear superiority in a class. Open fields made sniper the best, defensive made the engineer the best (except for building over turrets being sometimes a thing), offense was the commando, and the miner was just sort of a for fun character who lacked a real strong point.

Weapons: There are few choices for each class, and then spaces that look liked locked choices, but with no explanation how to unlock them or if they are just unadded things to keep the menu aligned since some slots fill across and others don't. With such limited weapon choices, picking a class kind of locks in weapon choices and doesn't allow you to really make the character work your way.


Needs to be a little more clear on how things work, and then I might upvote it.

I do NOT recommend this game. It is a rushed and buggy release (somewhat improved by the last update), probably done so because the company releasing it are close to going under. The lack of community-hosted servers is bad enough on its own, but combine this with the fact that the company could be gone in 3 months, it makes purchasing it a bit of a risk.

tl;dr Rude, not reading my words, but yes, don't buy this game.

reviewText:
Wait, is that a sni-... Yes, snipers, snipers everywhere. The biggest problem of this game. Like 8/10 of all players play with a sniper and there is no way you can avoid them. The lasers the developers implemented helped for spotting snipers but after all it can't be helped, you have to face them no matter what.

Snipers are actually part of a vicious circle: Killing people with a sniper is pretty easy since most of the maps are vast and open and making headshots isn't that hard. All the other weapons can hardly kill a sniper from medium to long distance but the sniper can, so you almost always have the disadvantage when not using a sniper. In order to kill those snipers and get a chance to kill others too those people also take the sniper. This results in more people using the sniper and also more people not being able to play properly due to all the snipers, so they take the sniper too. And so on...

Furthermore:

- Decent amount of maps although none of them are sniper-proof since most of the maps are very vast and open.
- Low amount of weapons and tools, even after 2½ years no new ones are implemented. You will mostly play with a sniper since most of the other weapons are useless against your sniper enemies, combined with the many vast open maps you literally have no other choice.
- Good amount of game modes but team deathmatch and zombie are overrepresented and the others are barely played.
- Lots of griefers, literally everything gets demolished. Some people only seem to play this game for the sake of screwing around and ruining the gameplay for others. They preferably destroy spawns, the enemies' and yours.
- The team balancing is awful. Everytime you're in the bad losing team your spawn gets destroyed and everyone gets spawn killed resulting in people quitting, your team gets worse and spawn destroying and killing gets even easier for the enemy team and from there the vicious circle starts again while nothing gets balanced.
- The map builder is ok but not all that special. It has a decent amount of settings and prefabs to use but I personally don't find it a builder to make perfect maps with.
- Kinda low amount of players. I definently think this will continue to drop since the developers are not improving the game.
- Almost no new updates and improvements.

Summarized: Lots of snipers and griefers, low amount of weapons of which the sniper is mostly used, decent amount of maps only most are too open and vast, good amount of game modes but lots of them are barely played, awful team balancing, decent map builder, kinda low amount of players & almost no new updates and improvements.

4/10.

reviewText:
Ace of Spades is a very unique twist in the FPS Genre, mixing in elements like Minecraft and Call of Duty to make an experience that hasn't been done by many other games. The main features in a nutshell is that the terrain is destructable and you can build bunkers and bases or sniper towers and so forth. The game is very fun, especially when you get good at it and change a few of the controls but it does have some problems like that some maps have the issue of one side clearly having the upper hand and that there will almost always be a camper on a server. There are no classes that are over-powered or unbalanced and you have to train with them for them to be any good on the battlefield.

It is practically a multiplayer-only game but servers are far from empty and there are a lot of game modes to try out and you can create your own maps. The Steam workshop for this is very basic but still good and fun to try out fans' maps. As every game has, the game suffers from bugs but the game-breaking ones have been removed. Graphics can be altered as well for better frame rates.

Overall, this game is a must buy if you want a FPS with a interesting twist and I give it a 7.5/10.

reviewText:
Gra Ace of Spades, obwołana została Minecraftem FPS-ów, co z uwagi na wielki sukces produkcji studia Mojang, jest bardzo zachęcającą rekomendacją. Wszystkich zapaleńców, którym marzy się możliwość budowy własnych fortów oraz walki na śmierć i życie z przeciwną drużyną na własnych mapach – muszę z przykrością rozczarować. Gra jest po prostu średnią strzelanką, a jej jedyne podobieństwo do wspomnianego wcześniej Minecrafta, to świat zrobiony z sześcianów.



Jak zacząć?

Ace of Spades jest nietypową produkcją i szczerze powiedziawszy, nie mam pojęcia od której strony ją ugryźć, żeby rozpocząć recenzję. Z jednaj strony mamy świetny pomysł, bo któż z tych, co Minecraft przypadł do gustu, nie marzył o możliwości epickich starć z innymi graczami na zaprojektowanych przez siebie mapach? Z drugiej strony, mamy tutaj masę zmarnowanego potencjału, gdyż budowa nie jest nawet w połowie tak precyzyjna, jak być powinna, a i czasu na nią w ogóle nie mamy.
Nachodzi mnie uczucie, że sami twórcy nie do końca wiedzieli, od której strony mają się za swoją grę zabrać, gdyż w żadnym swoim aspekcie nie osiąga mistrzostwa, przez co świetny pomysł skończył jako zwyczajny przeciętniak.
Czym jednak tak naprawdę jest Ace of Spades i jak się w to gra? Weźmy więc dla porównania dowolną strzelankę online i już jesteśmy w domu – przynajmniej na początek. Wybieramy z listy serwer, bądź pozwalamy wrzucić się na losowy (co odradzam, gdyż zazwyczaj kończyłem na pustych serwerach), czekamy chwilę na załadowanie mapy. Te są z reguły sporych rozmiarów i pozwalają na swobodne przemieszczanie się po całym terenie w poszukiwaniu wroga lub innych celów, które różnią się w zależności od trybów rozgrywki. Tak jak każdy szanujący się dzisiaj FPS, tak i Ace of Spades daje nam możliwość wyboru klasy, a nawet umożliwia w bardzo ograniczony sposób wybór broni. Profesje są cztery – Commando, Miner, Marksman i Rocketeer. Każdy z nich ma swój zestaw oręża, tak więc Commando biega z bazooką lub minigunem. Miner dostaje w swoje ręce ładunki wybuchowe, shotguna i coś w rodzaju połączenia wiertła z bazooką, Marksman prowadzić powinien ostrzał z daleka za sprawą swojej snajperki. Rocketeer natomiast potrafi szybko przemieszczać się po mapie za sprawą jetpacka i sprowadzać na wrogów śmierć z wysoka swoim wiernym karabinkiem. To jednak nie wszystko, każda z klas ma do swojej dyspozycji łopatę, służącą nie tylko do walki wręcz, ale również do kopania (o czym więcej za chwilę), klocek do budowy oraz zestaw kilku przygotowanych struktur.
Struktury te różnią się w zależności od klasy, którą wybierzemy. Znajdziemy między nimi schody, bunkry, platformy, zasieki, itp. Bardzo łatwo jest je zniszczyć, tak jak i resztę terenu, jednakże, dobrze rozplanowane, potrafią dać drużynie nieznaczną chwilę przewagi.



Buduj i niszcz

Jedną z największych różnić, które sprawiają, że Ace of Spades ma szansę zaistnienia na rynku Battlefieldów i CoD-ów jest możliwość wpływania na otoczenie. Wszystko, na co padną nasze oczy, możemy zniszczyć czy zabudować. Podstawowym narzędziem destrukcji jest saperka – składana łopatka, która służy również do zabijania wrogów wręcz. Kopanie nią jest dosyć chaotyczne i trudno mówić tutaj o jakiejkolwiek precyzji, jednak do szybkiego przebicia się przez ścianę nadaje się idealnie. Jeśli jednak nasza żądza zniszczenia nie zostanie zaspokojona małą łopatką, klasa Minera powinna dać upust destrukcyjnym zapędom. Garść dynamitów i wspomniane wcześniej wiertło, potrafią w kilka sekund stworzyć tunel lub wyrwę w najgrubszej ścianie.
Niestety, nie ma tutaj podziału na materiały, z jakich świat jest zrobiony. Każdy klocek rozpada się równie szybko, niezależnie czy jest to ściana, piasek czy wrak metra. Budowanie z pojedynczych bloków natomiast jest przydatne jedynie w momencie zablokowania dziury w murze, gdyż budowa czegoś większego mija się zwyczajnie z celem. Z pomocą przychodzą tutaj predefiniowane struktury, które postawić możemy jednym kliknięciem, jednak bazy operacyjnej z ich pomocą nie postawimy.


Walcz i giń

Arsenał jest dosyć oklepany i jego niuanse opisałem już wcześniej. W tym rozdziale recenzji postaram się opisać najważniejszy aspekt FPS-ów, czyli jaką frajdę daje w tej grze strzelanie. Osobiście przyznam, że małą. Amunicja kończy się strasznie szybko, więc warowanie się nie ma najmniejszego sensu, gdyż udać musimy się w takim wypadku do paczki z amunicją, która wraz z apteczką spawni się w wybranym miejscu mapy. Większość czasu grałem jako Rocketeer, gdyż uzależniłem się od jetpacka i zwyczajnie uciążliwym stało się bieganie po mapie za sprawą własnych nóg. Do dyspozycji miałem więc karabin, który dużą celnością pochwalić się nie mógł, tak samo zresztą jak i zadawanymi obrażeniami, przez co musiałem wystrzelać nie raz dwa (celne!) magazynki, żeby wroga ubić.
To jedynie moje odczucia, jednak wydaje mi się, że walka, co jest kluczowym elementem gry, nie została do końca dopracowana. Strzelanie do wroga po prostu przyprawiło mi więcej frustracji niż radochy.



Kwadratem być

Oprawa graficzna jest dosyć szczególna i czy będzie się podobać, zależy wyłącznie od gustu. Wszystko zbudowane zostało z sześcianów, jednakże, w przeciwieństwie do Minecrafta, są one dużo mniejsze, przez co twórcy uzyskali znacznie większą szczegółowość modeli postaci czy broni. Sam świat natomiast, nie potrafi wprawić w zachwyt, tak jak wyżej wymieniona produkcja od Mojang, gdyż tekstury nałożone na kwadraty są jednolite, przez co wszystko wygląda szaroburo. Samo niebo niestety jest obrazem o niskiej rozdzielczości, co tylko potęguje uczucie brzydoty otaczającego świata. Sytuacje ratują niektóre mapy, ukazujące majestatyczne katedry czy wzgórza, udowadniając nam, że odrobina pracy mogłaby zmienić cały wystrój gry na dużo atrakcyjniejszy.
Do udźwiękowienia nie mam natomiast najmniejszych zastrzeżeń. Dźwięki broni są solidne, każdy strzał, każdy wybuch brzmi tak, jak brzmieć powinien. W tle przygrywa radosna muzyczka, swoim stylem nawiązująca do produkcji z automatów. Niekoniecznie musi się ona podobać, nie można jej jednak odmówić swoistego klimatu pasującego do całej gry.

Zdecydowanie, Ace of Spades nie powinno być tak ostentacyjnie porównywane do Minecrafta. Pomimo drobnych podobieństw, różnice są tak wielkie, że nie ma mowy o jakimkolwiek zestawianiu tych gier ze sobą. Recenzowana przeze mnie produkcja jest wykonana solidnie, jednak wiele jej aspektów powinno jeszcze zostać dopracowanych. Uważam, że wielu graczy z przyjemnością przywitałoby jakiś system rozwoju postaci, odblokowania nowych broni czy możliwości zaprojektowania własnych budynków. reviewText:
The Battle of the Blocks

Ace of Spades is the first person,32 player, Team Fortress 2 and Minecraft inspired love child by Jagex Limited. AoS takes the best innovations from other hit games such as TF2 and Minecraft to make something unique. Aos is a multiplayer only game that takes TF2's class system with a Minecraft's look and creation and destruction. There are 4 main classes each with special abilities and weapons in Aos; The Marksman, Engineer, Commando, and Miner. In this team based shooter it is important to utilize the classes correctly to actually work as a team. There is such a diverse way of the playing the game that there will not be session where you will play the same map the same way. For example you need to capture a flag within a castle. Instead of generically storming the front door, you can fly to the top, break the walls down, dig underneath it, or even build a tower to get inside. The way of taking of objectives are really up to the imagination of the player and his or her team. Also in AoS, boring maps are not a thing. The maps included in AoS is extremely varied, everything from defending a castle from invading ships, Moonbase, to a map with a huge dinosaur in the middle! and the inclusion of the Steam Workshop allows users to create&post  their own maps, so there is basically endless possibilities for maps. The game modes include Capture the Flag, Demolition, Team Deathmatch, King of the hill and much much more. But by far the Zombie mode was my favorite. Out of all the players, 1 starts out infected and goal is to infect other players. Slowly one by one the survivors began to dwindle and the undead began to rise. Panic begins to rise on the survivor team while they frantically try to defend their towers they built. The mode is loads of fun especially when with friends or having a talkative team. Unfortunately that is also the problem with the game. If you are not playing with friends and using strategy the game can become a mess and loose its fun. Also I noticed that finding a nearly full game was difficult. I would click the ranked or player matches and it would load me into a empty lobby. Fortunately they recently added a server browser. Its a same that the game has more empty servers than actual players because the game is actually really fun and worth the money. Plus the soundtrack is pretty good too :) .

Overall
Ace of Spades is a great game that takes the best of games and puts them together. Incredibly fun combat with teamwork and great original game modes as well as a vast supply of unique maps make this game a great experience with friends. Otherwise it kinda falls flat. If you can find a match that is, it is worth a buy, to play for a weekend at least.

Verdict:
8.0 Good

reviewText: This game tries to be a combination of Minecraft and Team Fortress 2, but fails to be either. Almost every server is laggy and unplayable. The hit detection barely works, so an enemy in the middle of your crosshairs will not get hit while you are killed with an SMG from across the map. The store page claims that there are seven different classes when there are only 4 in the game. The building is barely functional and very difficult to use. You won't be doing too much building, though, as the Rocketeer class can use his jetpack to bypass any defenses you have. Actually, all of the classes are terribly balanced. Very rarely are you killed and feel like your killer deserved it. The animations are laughable, and the fact that the game tries so hard to make everything blocky makes it look terrible. Minecraft's visuals have a charm to them. They are simple. The models in this game look awful and complicated, as if the developers couldn't decide between having the game look nice or looking blocky. When you join a game, it asks which team you want to join, although you will always be moved to the team with less players. What's the point of giving a choice if it is undone? Another weird part of the game is that the class selection screen includes multiple weapons and gadgets that you can use. There are at most two options in each category, although there are many empty boxes for each class, as if they were planning on adding weapon variety to the game.\nTo sum up, Ace of Spades is a badly made game that is going through an identity crisis, not sure whether it is a sandbox building game or a terribly balanced class-based shooter. 3/10

reviewText:
Ace of Spades is a multiplayer combat game combining Minecraft style physics with Cod/TF2 gameplay. This leads to an interesting style of combat that rewards people for their skill and ingenuity in crafting the landscape and building structures to their tactical advantage.

I have spent nearly 300 hours playing this game and the main thing that keeps me playing is the fun factor.  There are always people online obviously not as many as with some fps games but you can always get a match by using the server browser. The gameplay itself is also a main factor in its durability. As the environment is buildable you can create buildings and mould the landscape into something that allows you to outwit your opponents.

With it being in the steam workshop you can download user –created maps for use which adds endless variety.

While the graphics may not be for everyone, people that have played games such as Minecraft or more indie style games probably won’t mind.  I guess a bonus of this is that it runs smoothly . I only experience the odd, very occasional bit of lag.

Pro’s:
-	Great for lovers of first person shooters.
-	 Multiple classes to use to your advantage.
-	Tactical gameplay.
-	Plenty of games available and a good range of maps that come as standard.
-	Custom Maps.
-	Range of game modes spanning from Team Deathmatch to Capture the Flag and ‘Zombie’.

Con’s:
-	Lots of trolls and people that try and kick you for hacking if you are much better than them.
-	Small infrequent DLC.
-	No skill tree/ weapon advancement.
-	A few bugs which aren’t too big a deal.
-	Not a large emphasis on teamwork.


I don’t usually put this many hours into a game so with that in mind (and its low price tag) I’d definitely recommend Ace of Spades!    8.5/10

reviewText: Ace of Spades was one of my favorite games of all time, until its sole developer sold it to a major gaming company (You can still play the original at buildandshoot.com!). They scrapped the game and rebuilt it from the ground up - and not very well. At this point, it's a sub-par FPS which awkwardly integrates building into much-too-short games filled with unbalanced, unrealistic, and frankly unfun classes. The maps are highly limited in number and not creative nor interesting. The graphics were created to vaguely resemble the style of the real game, but in the end, are frankly just weird-looking.  I tried to like the new version, I really did, but after several hours of play, I would not reccomend it.
